title: Colts get positive Anthony Richardson injury news after preseason scare
description: Despite the gruesome appearance of a dislocated pinkie, Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson appeared to escape with just a minor injury after all.
content:
Despite the gruesome appearance of a dislocated pinkie finger and the optics of it being the latest worry in a career already full of them, Anthony Richardson appeared to escape with just a minor injury after all.

The Colts quarterback could return to practice as soon as Saturday, ESPN reported, after X-rays Thursday night — during halftime of Indianapolis’ preseason opener against the Ravens — were negative and Richardson was initially considered day-to-day.

The outlet added that Richardson even made some light throws on the sideline before getting ruled out, an early sign the No. 4 overall pick in 2023 is avoiding the worst.

Richardson’s injury occurred midway through the opening quarter — on just the Colts’ second drive of the game — when Ravens linebacker David Ojabo raced toward Richardson unblocked from the left side of the defensive line and dropped the signal-caller for a sack.

Colts head coach Shane Steichen told reporters postgame that Richardson’s pinkie finger “popped out,” and Indianapolis medical staff popped it back in, according to ESPN.

But it wasn’t worth the risk of having Richardson attempt to continue playing, with the 23-year-old in an ongoing competition alongside Daniel Jones for the starting job.

Richardson got the start in the opener, and Jones was supposed to start their second preseason game against the Cowboys on Aug. 16, but it’s unclear if Steichen’s plans will change after Jones entered Thursday and completed 10-of-21 passes during the Colts’ 24-16 loss.

Before exiting, Richardson, who has started 15 games while collecting 21 total touchdowns and 13 interceptions across an up-and-down first two seasons, went 2-for-3 for 21 yards.

He has also dealt with shoulder, back, foot and hip injuries, as well as a concussion, since joining the NFL.

“I feel like I was doing decent out there, besides that one play right there,” Richardson told reporters postgame, according to The Washington Post. “But everything happens for a reason. Still got next game, so I’m not too worried about it.”

Jones, formerly the Giants’ $160 million quarterback who was released in the middle of last season, signed a one-year, $14 million deal with the Colts to compete for the starting job and revive his career after joining the Vikings’ practice squad late in 2024.
summary: Anthony Richardson, the Colts quarterback, may return to practice as soon as Saturday after a dislocated pinkie finger during the team's preseason opener against the Ravens. The injury occurred mid-game, but X-rays were negative and Richardson was initially considered day-to-day. Despite making some light throws on the sideline, Richardson appears to be avoiding the worst. This injury comes as part of a larger injury to Richardson's career, which has included shoulder, back, foot, and hip injuries. Richardson is currently competing with Daniel Jones for the starting job with the Colts.
shortSummary: Despite a dislocated pinkie finger during Indianapolis’s preseason game against the Ravens, Anthony Richardson is expected to return to practice as soon as Saturday after X-rays proved positive.

scraped_sources.text:
Daniel Jones’ Colts debut did not look much different from his Giants career.
Jones entered Thursday’s 24-16 preseason loss to the Ravens earlier than expected when Anthony Richardson went down with a dislocated pinky on his throwing hand in the first quarter.
The Duke product finished his night with 10 completions on 21 attempts for 144 yards. He committed no turnovers but did not lead any touchdown drives.
“Got to be ready to go. That’s part of the game,” Jones said of replacing the injured Richardson. “Some good, some bad. Caught a rhythm there I think at points, and we were moving the ball well, executing, but a couple things here and there kept us from getting in the end zone.”
Before leaving with the injury, Richardson completed 2 of 3 attempts for 21 yards.
The two are in a battle for the starting quarterback position, but Jones didn’t necessarily get a leg up with his up-and-down play after Richardson went down.
Jones took over on third down during the Colts’ second drive, approximately eight minutes into the game, and handled all the quarterback reps until halftime as Notre Dame rookie Riley Leonard played the second half.
In Jones’ first full drive, he passed for one first down before Indianapolis was forced to punt on the next set of downs. Jones was sacked for a loss of nine yards on third down.
His next time out, Jones led the Colts to a field goal, utilizing two big pass plays of over 20 yards.
Jones followed up the scoring drive with another one-first-down series that ended in a punt and two more drives that wound up in field-goal range, with Colts kicker Spencer Shrader converting one of the kicks.
Leonard handled the entire second half, but was unimpressive as he tallied 92 yards on 12-for-24 passing with an interception. He added 34 rushing yards, highlighted by a 21-yard scamper, and helped lead the team to its lone touchdown drives.
After the game, Indianapolis head coach Shane Steichen said Richardson’s pinky “popped out, popped back in.”
Jones joined the Colts in the offseason on a one-year, $14 million contract for the opportunity to duel with the former fourth-overall pick in Richardson, who has battled injury and inconsistent play through his first two seasons.
— with AP

Across both teams, veteran players will likely sit out, giving younger and secondary players a chance to shine.
The Ravens will play new talent like their first-round draft pick Malaki Starks and second-year safeties Sanoussi Kane and Beau Brade, both in the running to be the team’s No. 3 in the role.
The Colts’ quarterback competition will also kick into full gear with 2023 fourth overall draft pick Anthony Richardson, who will be in action for a quarter-and-a-half against the Ravens (next week, former Giant Daniel Jones will play with the same setup).

Anthony Richardson knocked out of first preseason game in Colts injury worry
Anthony Richardson’s 2025 preseason debut didn’t last long.
Just eight minutes into the first quarter of the Colts’ loss to the Ravens on Thursday night, Richardson was leveled by an unblocked David Ojabo and was forced to leave the game.
While the hit looked fairly vicious and was initially presumed as an arm injury, it was later designated as a dislocated pinky, and Richardson was ruled out for the remainder of the game.
Indianapolis head coach Shane Steichen later said Richardson’s pinky “popped out, popped back in.”
Steichen ruled Richardson as day-to-day.
“I feel like I was doing decent out there, besides that one play right there,” Richardson said, according to NFL.com. “But everything happens for a reason. Still got next game, so I’m not too worried about it.”
He attempted just three passes and completed two of them for 21 yards before exiting.
Richardson is freshly recovered from a shoulder injury setback that forced him to miss the final two weeks of the Colts’ practices in June.
The signal-caller is in the midst of the quarterback duel with former Giant Daniel Jones, who took over for Richardson when he exited.
Jones played the rest of the first half and completed just 10 of 21 passes for 144 yards. Rookie Riley Leonard out of Notre Dame took over the quarterback reps in the second half.
Jones is in his first season with Indianapolis after signing a one-year, $14 million contract after spending six years with the Giants and a brief stint with the Vikings, while Richardson is in just his third year after being drafted by the Colts with the fourth overall pick in 2023.
Richardson played just four games during his rookie campaign before suffering a season-ending shoulder injury. He helped lead the Colts to a 2-2 record while tallying seven total touchdowns and one interception.
In his sophomore season in 2024, he played in 11 games while missing contests because of two separate injuries and being benched for veteran Joe Flacco.
Richardson threw just eight touchdowns to 12 interceptions when he did play, but added six rushing touchdowns.

INDIANAPOLIS -- Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson Sr. could return to practice as soon as Saturday after sustaining a dislocated right pinkie in Thursday night's preseason opener, sources told ESPN.
Richardson was sacked forcefully by unblocked Baltimore Ravens linebacker David Ojabo in the first quarter, leaving the smallest finger on his throwing hand bent at an outward angle as he ran off the field.
Members of the team's medical staff quickly popped the joint back into place, and Richardson began testing his ability to grip a football in hopes of returning to the game. He resumed throwing light passes on the sideline. But by then, coach Shane Steichen had made the decision to rule him out of the game, with veteran Daniel Jones finishing the first half before yielding to rookie Riley Leonard in the second half.
Richardson underwent X-rays at halftime, which were negative, sources said.
Colts players have a scheduled day off Friday but return to training camp in Westfield, Indiana, on Saturday. If Richardson can throw the ball effectively, he is likely to be on the field.
After the game, Richardson said the finger was "tender," adding, "it'll be a little bit more so in the morning. But I'll be good."
Less clear is how the Colts will handle their quarterback situation moving forward. They have divided starting reps mostly equally between Richardson and Jones, and Steichen had planned to give Richardson extensive playing time in the preseason opener, with Jones slated to see expanded playing time next week. But after Jones came off the bench to play the final 23 minutes of the first half Thursday, that plan went out the window.
Richardson completed 2 of 3 passes before his injury. Jones entered and completed 10 of 21 passes for 144 yards.

argos_summary: Colts quarterback Anthony Richardson suffered a dislocated pinkie finger during the preseason opener against the Ravens but is expected to return to practice as soon as Saturday after negative X-rays. The injury occurred when he was sacked by Ravens linebacker David Ojabo, leading to his early exit from the game. Veteran Daniel Jones took over quarterback duties, completing 10 of 21 passes for 144 yards, but did not significantly improve his standing in the competition for the starting job.
